data.title: Set name in productName in shipped package.json based on channel
data.body:
These fields are used by grunt-electron-installer. We need to parameterize
them based on the channel so Atom Beta and Atom can coexist on windows.

Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9247

data.title: Atom Beta isn't Side by Side on Windows
data.body:
**Expected**
According to the [beta info page](https://atom.io/beta) Atom Beta should "run side-by-side with Atom stable". To me that reads like I should be able to have both the beta and stable installed (and even running) simultaneously on the same system (like with Chrome's stable & beta releases) and there should be separate links to run each build.

**Actual**
On Windows (7 x64), when I install the beta (`1.1.0-beta1`), it replaces the context menu "Open with Atom" shortcut and the start menu shortcuts with the beta so there is no apparent way to run stable without reinstalling.
Reinstalling stable works but it replaces all the shortcuts with links to the stable version so there is no way to run the beta without re-installing.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2421069/10649437/18a1a58c-783c-11e5-8c7c-fe4be8b6a49d.png)

data.title: Atom crashes when pasting clipboard image into editor
data.body: I am using Mac OS X 10.11 with Atom 1.0.19. When opening a bitmap image with OS X's "Preview", copying it and CMD + V into the Atom editor, Atom crashes. It usually crashes, but it has succeeded a few times. It seems like it wants to paste this: `![Alt text](/Users/xxx/.atom/evnd/tmp/clipboard_20151021_214154.png "Optional title")` The clipboard image I wish to paste is 2804 × 1544 px.

data.body:
I tried searching for this issue, but didn't come up with anything. If this is a dupe, I apologize. 

I can select multiple files in the tree view, but when I try to move the selected files, it only moves one.

You can see this behavior in the following video: 
![moving_files_in_tree](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/461514/10645853/b6abce68-77e4-11e5-8124-3f0d2c177d60.gif)

This is on Atom 1.0.19 on Mac OS X 10.10.5.

data.title: Fix Build Issues For Node v4 and apm v1.3.0+
GitRepository getDirectoryStatus mishandles project root directory
data.body:
When passed a project root directory, `getDirectoryStatus` relativizes the path into a "/". As a result, subsequent checks never match any path, since they do not start with "/". The directory status of the root is always returned as zero.

Here is the current code from git-repository.coffee; note the trailing slash at `@relativize`:

``` coffee
getDirectoryStatus: (directoryPath)  ->
    directoryPath = "#{@relativize(directoryPath)}/"
    directoryStatus = 0
    for path, status of @statuses
      directoryStatus |= status if path.indexOf(directoryPath) is 0
    directoryStatus
```

Suggestions:
- Change this so that `directoryStatus` is correctly calculated when given the project root
- For performance consider using `.startsWith()` or `.lastIndexOf(str, 0)` for path comparison so that entire strings are not compared
- Consider early exit from the loop if the maximum possible value of `directoryStatus` is reached and logical OR of more bits won't change things (not sure what the maximum is)

Motivation for change and references:

Highlight git changes on the level of a project
https://github.com/atom/tree-view/issues/564

`getDirectoryStatus` code
https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/git-repository.coffee#L305

String prefix
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/646628/how-to-check-if-a-string-startswith-another-string#4579228

data.title: Add an option on atom-text-editor to make it read-only
data.body:
Currently in Nuclide, we create a subclass of `TextEditor` named `ReadOnlyTextEditor` to try to make a read-only version:

https://github.com/facebook/nuclide/blob/1fdf2b98/pkg/nuclide/ui/atom-text-editor/lib/ReadOnlyTextEditor.js
1. This is pretty hacky and tough to maintain because it's hard to be sure that we have blocked off all reasonable entry points that could mutate things.
2. Currently on master, the new refactoring of `TextEditor` that frowns on using the constructor directly and strongly pushes for the use of `atom.workspace.buildTextEditor()` breaks our existing use of `extends TextEditor` in implementing `ReadOnlyTextEditor`.

We can work around this using a new hack (will link once the diff is up), but it would be nice to have proper support for this in Atom. We use `TextEditor` in a number of places as a UI element to show things like console logs.

I'll try to put up my own fix for this when I get a chance, but I'm filing this to have a placeholder for now.

/cc @nathansobo @maxbrunsfeld

data.title: Highlighting lines takes 10% of the CPU?
data.body:
### Atom Version: 1.0.19
### Environment: Archlinux
### Repro steps:

1) Open a project folder
2) Open a file (must have some lines in it, more than 10 makes it easier to reproduce)
3) Hold double-click to select an entire line (keep holding it)
4) Move mouse down to select a few more lines
5) Wiggle your mouse up and down and notice that:
- two processes go from taking 0% of the processor to 10%+
- fan speed increases! (side effect)
### Actual behavior:
#### Process 1:

/usr/share/atom/atom --type=gpu-process --channel=4927.0.1668123424 --no-sandbox --supports-dual-gpus=false --gpu-driver-bug-workarounds=2,27,30,43,52 --disable-accelerated-video-decode --gpu-vendor-id=0x10de --gpu-device-id=0x1187 --gpu-driver-vendor=NVIDIA --gpu-driver-version=355.11
- increases by 13% for a simply highlighting lines?
#### Process 2:

/usr/share/atom/atom --type=renderer --force-device-scale-factor=1 --js-flags=--harmony --no-sandbox --enable-deferred-image-decoding --lang=en-US --node-integration=true --subpixel-font-scaling=false --enable-pinch-virtual-viewport --enable-delegated-renderer --num-raster-threads=2 --use-image-texture-target=3553 --disable-accelerated-video-decode --channel=4927.1.2045218742
- increases by ~12%

Expected behavior:
For a simple task such as highlighting lines, is it reasonable to not expect 10% of my processor being used?

Additional Information:
processor: i7-930
gpu: nvidia gtx 760

data.title: Take 2: Pass current options when loading from previous window state
data.body:
Fixes #9233

This makes atom --profile-startup work correctly even if Atom isn't running when the command is executed.

I accidentally left the commit on master which marked the previous PR (#9234) as merged. I force-pushed to master seconds after it happened to correct the issue, so I'm opening this again.

This makes `atom --profile-startup` work correctly even if Atom isn't running when the command is executed.

data.title: --profile-startup flag doesn't record a profile when launching Atom for the first time with no path
data.body:
More context here: https://github.com/atom/docs/pull/136#issuecomment-149606128

@kevinsawicki mentioned:

> Hmm, I wonder if the timeout needs to be bumped in https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/806b46bb6c981f110a34ed20f566de50288900d0/static/index.js#L143-L145
> 
> There seemed to be issues in past Electron versions where you needed to wait a bit to start profiling after the devtools opened event fired.

I tried bumping the timeout to 500ms and that did fix the problem for me. But I'm not sure what a good timeout would be so opening this to track the issue.

cc @kevinsawicki @nathansobo

data.title: Make default-state of flags for find/replace configurable
data.body: As of now, at least for me, every time I start Atom and hit cmd+f to do find/replace I have to manually set the regex + case-sensitivity flag. Can you please make the default-state of these flags configurable in the settings, or just store them from the last session? In Sublime the flags are remembered even after closing/restarting the application (i.e. really quitting, not just hiding). I find this really inconvenient in Atom right now. Sorry if there already is some mechanism of doing this, I just couldn't find anything for it.

data.title: Possible memory leak w/ cut & paste operations.
data.body:
As suggested in issue #1827, I'm opening a new issue.

I've had to do alot of refactoring recently, which has required a lot of cut and paste. I've had to restart Atom more frequently, leading me to ask "why now?"

When I run a heap dump, the events object seems to just grow and grow, suggesting a leak. I haven't been able to test extensively, but a quick inspection of the events object suggests the text snippet is stored in memory, but never seems to be released. I would expect a cut operation to copy the snippet, but when I cut another snippet of text, I would expect the content of the original cut to be released from memory.

My tests have been pretty unscientific, but suggestive. I am cutting/pasting an average of 40-50 lines of code at a time. When I cut several larger snippets in reasonably quick succession, say 400 lines of code, memory consumption appears to increase more rapidly (and remain high).

I've disabled every 3rd party plugin and several core plugins. Copy/paste appears to work decently... so I've been able to work around things by copying code and deleting it, then pasting it. It's an annoying way to work though a refactor though.

I've also noticed the Atom helper typically reaching 1.9GB according to the activity monitor, but my overall RAM consumption hits 31.2 GB (of 32GB). As soon as I kill the process, it drops to 20GB total consumption.

All of this was primarily experienced on OSX (Mavericks & El Capitan) with an i5 CPU and 32GB of RAM. I've also experienced these issues on my Windows 8.1 laptop (i7 with 12GB RAM) with no change after upgrading to Win 10.

Finally, I do a fair amount of work with Electron and do not see memory issues like this in many of my apps, albeit my text editors are substantially less complex than Atom. I bring this up only because this (to me) suggests an issue with the Atom app, not the underlying Electron platform. 

I hope this helps in some way. It's reaching a point for me personally where I may have to abandon Atom due to sheer lack of productivity with it. I really hope I don't have to do that!

data.title: Omit the PHP tag
data.body: Is that possible create a PHP file and not use the <?php tag?

data.title: Command Line Parameter to set Atom to Portable Mode
data.body:
This is an enhancement to Portable Mode PR #8442 to provide a command line parameter for Atom to automatically set up a Portable Mode directory (a .atom directory as a sibling to the directory containing the Atom executable).

This uses -p and --set-portable
as a straw-man example of what would be the desired parameter.

This copies the .atom home from the default location to the portable location, assuming someone who has been using Atom and wants to go portable would want to take with them what they have already installed/configured.  This may or may not be a good assumption.

data.title: Organize structure of CONTRIBUTING guidelines and add section on project structure
data.body:
This is the first step in improving our CONTRIBUTING guidelines so that it's more helpful to both users and maintainers. I'll split the work into separate pull requests as I work on them.

This pull requests changes the structure by introducing sections and also adds a section on Atom's project structure (packages). This section is mashup of @benogle's recent [blog post](http://blog.atom.io/2015/10/16/making-your-first-contribution.html) :sparkles:, [this forum post](https://discuss.atom.io/t/id-like-to-report-an-issue-request-an-enhancement-for-atom-where-on-github-do-i-do-that/19290) from @mnquintana :zap:, and the previous text we had on this in the guidelines.
I think this information is super-helpful for contributors and should live in this document.

[Rendered version](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/iz-update-contributors-guide/CONTRIBUTING.md) for easier reading.

cc @atom/feedback @atom/issue-triage for :eyes: and :thought_balloon:. :bow:

data.title: Blurry rendering when switching between Retina/Non-retina screens
data.body:
I use Atom on a MBPr (15" Late 2013) plugged into an Apple Thunderbolt Display. When I unplug the external display while Atom is running the editor goes all blurry. And when I plug it back in again I see a weird rendering issue where only the top-left quarter of the editor is rendering.

![skarmavbild 2015-10-20 kl 13 21 35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/52966/10605783/77360c78-772e-11e5-93d0-99784452f44e.png)

_Atom running on an Apple Thunderbolt Display._

![skarmavbild 2015-10-20 kl 13 21 48](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/52966/10605844/e829cf14-772e-11e5-8c66-06017cadab20.png)

_Atom on retina display after unplugging the Apple Thunderbolt Display. (The blurriness is most noticable when comparing the text in the window bar and the text in the editor)_

![skarmavbild 2015-10-20 kl 13 22 07](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/52966/10605886/3b5a4498-772f-11e5-8c07-fd549a373452.png)

_Atom running on Apple Thunderbolt Display after being disconnected and then re-connected._
## Repro Steps
1. Connect external monitor with different dpi than internal monitor
2. Start Atom
3. Disconnect external monitor
4. Connect external monitor

**Expected:** Atom should transition seamlessly between different DPIs.
**Actual:** Editor is blurry when switching from LDPI screen to HDPI screen and fails completely when transitioning back to LDPI again.
## Versions
- **Atom:**       1.0.19
- **OS:**         Mac OS X 10.11

---

data.title: Generated package (toggle sample package) can't right click
data.body:
Was following this tutorial.

https://atom.io/docs/v0.192.0/hacking-atom-package-word-count

When you toggle the sample package and you try right click, nothing happens - the only way to get rid of the "The Wordcount package is Alive! It’s ALIVE!”. is to open the command palette again.

data.title: .log files are sometimes not discovered
data.body:
I have a python project that generates a .log file. I've noticed since a few days this file is not discovered anymore by Atom. If I change the file extension to .md, everything is fine. It seems to concern only .log files.

I tried making a minimal test folder with just the log file, but in this case it is discovered.
I added my gitignore file with it, but file is also discovered.

I will try other things to find out what is going on, if someone wants to test it also I can provide an archive of the project.

Otherwise if you have python 3.4 installed, it is also possible to download the project at this commit https://github.com/Overdrivr/DistantIO, install the required module and run the application.py file once. This will generate the log file.

data.title: Window position gets restored even if out of visible area
data.body:
**Version:** Atom 1.0.19 on Windows 7 (64 Bit)

**Observed Behavior:**
I'm using Atom on my Laptop at different locations, some of which I have a second screen at. After using Atom on such a second screen lately I found the editor to restore its window position without a second screen available today, i.e. it moved itself out of the visible area on start.

**Expected Behavior:**
Before restoring its old position, Atom checks whether that position would place it outside the current visible area (defined by all installed screend and their resolution). If so, it just moves to some default position (e.g. `(0; 0)`).

**Workaround:**
There might be some easy tricks, but I was just lucky to have a program I regularly use to easily order my windows and that tool is able to move the window back into the visible area. Those who are not having such a tool may find [this solution from superuser.com](http://superuser.com/a/53590) useful (but as this issue hasn't been posted yet I assume as a regular screen-configuration-changer I'm part of a minority).

I don't see this as a major/important issue, but I wanted to report it for the sake of integrity. **If you're able to, please try to reproduce this. It may also just be an issue on my side.**

data.title: Atom always opens the chrome developer tools on startup.
